Don’t forget your lunch. Alma hands him a compact Fortnum & Mason basket and pats on his girth. He opens it to discover CELERY AND CARROT STICKS wrapped in Saran.

Luxurious, wood-paneled and very British. Hitch sits restlessly behind his desk, receiving his morning shave f his private barber, SILVIO. His longtime assistant, PEGGY ROBERTSON, 40s, crisp, British, fiercely protective of he boss, is going through a list of potential projects.
Fox is offering you The Diary of Anne Frank for the third time. Hitch directs his response to Silvio.
The audience would spend the entire picture waiting for Miss Frank to discover the corpse I'd hidden in the attic. Wouldn’t you agree, Silvio?
Si. Hitch reaches for a carrot stick and CRUNCHES it.
MGM wants you for the Ian Fleming book, Casino Royale, with Cary Grant. Definitely your style.

(again, turning to Silvio) Doesn't she know I just made that movie? It's called North by Northwest. And “style” is merely self-plagiarism. Silvio nods, then recommences the shave. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) I'm treading water, Peggy. I need something fresh. Something different. Without expensive stars like Cary Grant or Miss Kim Novak to pretty it up. Silvio unintentionally nicks Hitch’s face. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) A nice, clean, nasty little piece of work. Silvio hurriedly dabs away a speck of BLOOD. (CONTINUED )

I’ll see what I can find. Hitch motions for the barber to hold up the mirror. The i of his face overflows the small frame. Repulsed, he leans back his head and makes a hand motion for Silvio to SLIT THROAT.

INT. CHASEN’S RESTAURANT - DAY Alma lunches with screenwriter-novelist WHITFIELD COOK. “WHIT,” 50s, is Hitchcock's physical opposite -- dashing, razor-sharp and sophisticated. In fact he’d be at home in of his movies.
... Thank God I had a pocketful of pretzels. I was hiding in that props cupboard all night. (then) That’1l teach me to use a bedroom set instead of the real thing.
Serves you right. They laugh uproariously, quite at ease with each other.
Hitch always said your private life was in danger of being more entertaining than any of your plots. He pours Alma another glass of wine, not remotely insulte

I can’t believe he let me have you all to myself for a whole afternoon. Especially looking this beautiful. He clinks her glass. WHITFIELD COOK (CONT’D) Trés chic. Alma turns to look at the menu again.
All this relentless sycophancy is giving me indigestion. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )
(a smile) What are you after? He laughs, his eyes straying to a PRETTY WAITRESS passing Alma notices.
And how is your wife?
Elizabeth? (his eyes return to Alma) Over the moon since I promised her the dedication in my new novel. So what are you working on these days?
Hitch is going out of his mind looking for his next project. You know how unbearable he is when he doesn't have something lined up.
Almost as unbearable as when he does.
(laughing) Almost.
I meant you. What are you working on?
I'm satisfied spending time in my garden.

That is one lucky garden. Whit brings out a set of galleys and slides them across t tablecloth to her. WHITFIELD COOK (CONT’D) Actually, I was hoping you might be able to apply your considerable pruning skills to this. She looks down and reads the cover page. “Taxi to Dubrovn By Whitfield Cook.”
Ah. All is finally revealed. (CONTINUED )
He touches her hand, affectionately. She brushes it away, affectionately...
The most fun I ever had was working with you. She looks through the opening pages... taking her time... enjoying making him wait...
I suppose I could give it a look.

Hitchcock peeks avidly through the blinds at a smartly dressed KIM NOVAK-TYPE WOMAN hurrying along to some appointment or assignation... Hitch cranes to see who she meeting, but she moves tantalizingly out of sight. Hitch turns back with a sigh towards his desk, covered wi discarded newspaper clippings and boring story proposals. He sweeps them off his desk into the trash. INT. HITCHCOCK’S OUTER OFFICE - A MOMENT LATER A SHADOW looms over Peggy at her desk as she sifts throug another round of story ideas. It’s Hitchcock. He startles her.
Anything. Anything at all? He starts sifting through her tray. She notices the glass his hand.
Nothing suitable. Is that water or do I need to call Alma? He drains it playfully.

Gin. Mother’s ruin. But something’s caught his eye. A circled review of Antho Boucher’s column “CRIMINAL MINDS” in the New York Times Review of Books. He picks it up. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Boucher says this “Psycho” book by Robert Bloch is ‘fiendishly entertaining’. (CONTINUED )
It sounds ghastly. Everyone in town’s already passed.
And who is everyone?
The story department finished the coverage this morning.

Is this the one based on Ed Gein, the serial killer? He takes the coverage and reads for himself. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) “Graphic elements of brutal violence, voyeurism, transvestitism and incest.” Certainly not your average run of the mill nutcase, is he? He gives a grunt of approval.
You're kidding.
Peggy. This is the boy who dug up his own mother.

Completely engrossed as he sits reading “Psycho” in a cha by the fire of his elegant Bel Air home. He takes another gulp of wine when he hears Alma enter and slides the wine glass out of view. Alma pops her head in the door.
Hungry?
Famished. She disappears to take off her coat.
If you're good, maybe you can have a grapefruit later. (CONTINUED )
She comes back in again carrying some galleys, notices th title of Hitch’s book -- some trash called “Psycho.”
Whit gave me the galleys of his new book yesterday at lunch. I’ve already got some ideas on how you could adapt it. Hitch continues reading.
It’s elegant, sophisticated, full of intrigue --
The book or Mr. Whitfield Cook? She taps Hitch’s book dismissively with the galleys of “T to Dubrovnik.”
This might be the one, Alfred. He finally looks up.
Leave it on the night stand. As she leaves she points to Hitch’s ‘hidden’ wine glass.
There are calories in that, you know. But Hitch ignores her and turns to look out the window, h imagination starting to turn...
Ed enters the bedroom. His mother, Augusta, is in the bed faced away from him.

Aren’t you cold, ma? She doesn’t answer. We follow him to the dresser where he lingers a little too long over his mother’s open underwea drawer before grabbing the blue coverlet on the side. He comes over and spreads the extra blanket over her. Sti wearing his jacket, he takes off his shoes, gets into bed crawls up next to her. (CONTINUED )
ED GEIN (CONT’D) Don't be afraid, ma... I’m here... As he puts his arm around her and pulls her close, we rev his mother’s ghoulishly embalmed face.
A slant of moonlight finds Alma fast asleep until a FINGE nudges her awake. She lifts her satin sleep mask to see Hitchcock holding out his copy of “Psycho.”
Oh God. The look of obsession on his face is unmistakable.
Read the bit in the motel bathroom.
Now? He switches on the light by her bedside. She sits up, put her glasses and reads from the opened page.

"Mary started to scream, and then the curtains parted further and a hand appeared, holding a butcher's knife. It was the knife that, a moment later, cut off her scream... and her head.” (handing him back the book) Charming. Doris Day should do it as a musical. She hands him back the book.
This is nothing but low-budget horror movie claptrap. She turns off the light again and goes back to bed. A dee voice sounds from the darkness...

But what if someone really good made a horror movie? EXT. HITCHCOCK’S GARDEN - MORNING The Hitchcocks eat breakfast on the terrace watching the GARDENERS trim the bushes and rake leaves from the pool. (CONTINUED )

Just think of the shock value. Killing off your leading lady halfway through. Alma can feel Hitch looking at her, waiting for a respons Clearly he isn’t going to let this one go. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) You're intrigued. Admit it. She butters her toast, casually taunts him by adding a la spoon of marmalade.
Actually, I think it’s a huge mistake. Hitch falls silent, a chastised schoolboy.
You shouldn't wait till halfway through... Kill her off after 30 minutes.
Hitch enters with purpose, carrying a stack of photos and articles.
Peggy, I want you to summon your minions...
Minions. Certainly. And who might they be...? Hitch heads for his office, in no mood for wise cracks. H spreads out the articles on the desk. Photos and magazine articles about Ed Gein...
Get them started buying copies of “Psycho.” Peggy stands in the doorway, watching --
How many do you need?
All of them. I want every copy, nationwide. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )
Have them scour every book shop and library. “Psycho” is my next picture, and I don't want anyone to find out the ending until they see it in the theater. Peggy shakes her head.

All that celery’s affecting your brain. She walks over, notices the LIFE MAGAZINE headline : “HOU OF HORRORS STUNS NATION.” Stark black and white photograp expose the nightmarish decay of the Gein house...
Are you sure about this? This is so unlike you.
That’s exactly the point, my dear. Peggy watches uneasily as Hitchcock pores over the articl with delight.

+. Ten female heads with the tops sawn off, a dozen masks of human skin, and a pair of lips on a drawstring for a window shade. Hitch looks down sweetly at the circle of quietly horrifi expressions...
Is this really going to be you’re next picture, Mr. Hitchcock?
That is my intention, madam. Yes. Hitch taps the photo of ED GEIN.
I only wish he looked more like William Holden and less like Elmer Fudd. The other columnists scribble down the quote.
Am I the only one who finds this offensive?

I was hoping everyone would. I mean life is deeply offensive and disgusting, isn’t it? Hitch glides off without missing a beat, past the Servers arriving with more hors d'oeuvres from the kitchen. I’m going to need some research detailing a typical unmarried 30-year-old secretary from Phoenix, Arizona. He looks over at the pantry, where Alma can be glimpsed through the swinging door, putting food onto trays. (CONTINUED )

He forges on through the guests only to get waylaid by Le It is a classic Hitchcock moment, a character needing to someplace being held up by someone who wants to chat --

(re: the faces of the gossip columnists) I told you, Hitch. This thing’s strictly for the drive-in crowd. Hitch smiles tightly and extricates himself, heading on t the kitchen through more annoying guests --
Whit leans against the stove watching Alma expertly arran the next round of hors d'oeuvres coming in from the kitch
Now, if this were a Hitchcock picture what would two characters like us, married to other people, be saying?
You don’t have to pretend you’re not upset he hasn’t read it yet, you know.
I'm a big boy. I can take it.
Well, I loved it. What terrific fun it must have been to research.
Certainly more fun than reading those reviews. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

(then) Do you think he really will read it? Suddenly, over Whitfield's shoulder, Alma sees Hitch loom in the doorway. Whit notes the tiny change in her eyes an turns. WHITFIELD COOK (CONT’D) Speak of the devil. Hitch stares blankly at him while Alma turns and busies herself over the sink, hiding an almost imperceptible blu WHITFIELD COOK (CONT’D) I have to admit, Hitch, I ran all over town looking for a copy of “Psycho” but couldn't find a single one.

I wonder how that could have happened. Hitch sips his martini, a picture of innocence. Then lean to Whit’s ear and whispers - just like Whit leaned into Alma’s ear a moment earlier. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Don’t stop looking on my behalf. Peggy appears in the pass-through, beckoning Hitch to hur back into the living room.
Hitch returns to see the other GUESTS are now passing aro the GEIN PHOTOS. They look utterly confused and horrified a couple of them are even gathering their coats.
standing together watching.
I’ve seen happier faces on a school bus going over a cliff.
I told you it would be too much.
But they can’t stop looking, can they? He slurps his martini, sharing a smile with Lew.
Paramount President BARNEY BALABAN, 70s, ferocious, righteous, sits behind his impressive desk flanked by two CONSERVATIVELY-ATTIRED EXECUTIVES. Hitchcock and Wasserman sit across from them.
Audiences want to be shocked, Barney. They want something different. And this is it. He gestures to the untouched copy of “Psycho” in front of Balaban.
The truth is, Hitch, every time you want to do something “different” like The Wrong Man or Vertigo, someone loses money. Hitchcock stares unblinking, giving nothing away.
So we should stop trying to give them something new?

You owe Paramount one last picture, Hitch. Can't you do something like North by Northwest but for us this time instead of for MGM? Hitch’s stare remains inscrutable. BARNEY BALABAN (CONT’D) We've offered you dozens of perfectly good properties.
(imperiously) “Psycho.” Wasserman gives Balaban the same glacial stare. The Param executives shift uncomfortably.
No one respects the name Hitchcock more than Paramount. But even a talented man sometimes backs the wrong horse. (CONTINUED )
Are you telling me “no?” Balaban maintains a calm, pleasant front.
I think you know me better than that, Hitch. I would never say “no” to you. Hitch’s suppressed rage is building...but Balaban says nothing.
Hitch and Lew walk down the stairs and through the leafy courtyard past Hitch’s office.
What a putz. You know what his family did before they built those movie palaces? Ran a grocery store.
My father ran a grocery store.
Exactly. That's what I'm saying. He should show some respect. Hitch turns to Lew.
They think I’ve lost my touch, Lew. My association with television has cheapened me.
Are you referring to that deal I got you where Bristol-Meyers pays you twenty-nine grand an episode and you own the negative? That’s my kind of cheap.
They just want the same thing over and over. They’ve put me in a coffin and now they’re nailing down the lid. Lew puts a comforting hand on him...
Hitch, I will never let that happen. (CONTINUED )
Hitch doesn’t respond, Lew sensing the true depth of his friend’s melancholy.
How much do you think you can make this picture for?
Eight hundred thousand... Give or take. Lew digests the figure...
I have whisky in the car.
ALMA does afternoon laps in the pool. A contemplative Hitchcock wanders down to the pool side wearing black sunglasses and a business suit. He watches Alma a moment. Finally she notices him.
You're back early. He shrugs, then sits at the table to pour himself a glass lemonade. Alma gets out and towels herself off.
I'm disappointed you didn't give Whit’s book a chance.
What about him?
He knows you well enough. She sits down next to him, noticing a tiny hole in her swimsuit. It’s starting to look a little threadbare.
Enjoy the pool now. We might not have it for that much longer. He looks off cryptically.
Why? (CONTINUED )

Paramount refuses to finance the movie. Imagine -- The studio that brought you Martin and Lewis and The Greatest Show On Earth considers Psycho distasteful. He brushes some fallen leaves off his chair. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Lew can’t find the money. Not quickly enough at least.
Why not wait? He doesn’t reply. She knows him well enough too and doesn question him further. She looks
We're going to have to go it alone, old girl. (beat) We'll finance the movie ourselves.
Are we going to have to sell the entire house or just the pool? at Hitch but he’s not joking. She turns to survey their beloved home and gardens. A long pause. Pause.
Tell me and I won’t ever ask again. Why this one, Hitch? It’s not just because so many people are telling you 'no,' is it?
Hitch? Without turning he takes her hand.

Remember the fun we had when we started out and there was so little money and time? We took risks, we experimented. We invented new ways of making pictures because we had to. A long moment as he gazes across the pool. (CONTINUED )
ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) I want to feel that kind of freedom again. He turns to look into her eyes for the first time. A glim of the real Hitchcock. Someone even his wife doesn’t see often...
The famous gates and the executive building beyond it.

Barney, we're about to propose a restructured deal for “Psycho”... INT. BALABAN’S PRIVATE OFFICE, PARAMOUNT - DAY Balaban watches Hitchcock and Lew closely. Hitchcock agai like a waxworks Buddha, revealing nothing.
We finance it. Independently. Paramount only distributes it...in exchange for 40 percent of the profits.
Interesting. But tell us, what exactly is Paramount distributing? Is this still a picture about a queer killing people in his mother’s dress?
What this picture is about is the reputation of Alfred Hitchcock.
No-one’s arguing that.
Barney, it’s very simple. This is Mr. Hitchcock’s next film. Are you in or are you out? A long silence.
Well, obviously you have a lot of passion for this project. Let me talk it over with a few people internally and I’1l get back to you. (CONTINUED )
No. Now. Balaban takes in their inscrutable stares. Not unimpresse their chutzpah, he leans back and puts his hands behind h head, a king in his counting room.
Fine. We’ll take that deal. If you can get the money... Finally, Hitchcock speaks up :

We've already got it, Barney. He pulls out his PERSONAL CHECKBOOK and opens it on the d Barney watches as Hitch takes the onyx fountain pen from mount. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Who do I make it out to?
Hitch and Alma lie side by side in their separate beds. A copy of “The Dance of Death” by Strindberg lies on Hitch’ bedside table. All traces of his bravado are gone...
If this picture fails, Alma, we'll be in for a long, humiliating bout of crow- eating.
The movie will be splendid.
Are you sure?

Of the movie? Not in the least. But of you? Unquestionably. INT. HITCHCOCK’S OFFICE, PARAMOUNT - DAY PUDGY FINGERS part the slats of the blind. Hitch stares o hoping for some human moment to spy on. He’s restless... Peggy ushers JOSEPH STEFANO, 30s, into Hitch’s office.
Joe Stefano. Good to meet you. (CONTINUED )
Hitchcock leaves Stefano’s hand dangling in mid air and s down at his desk. JOSEPH STEFANO (CONT’D) Sorry I was late. My shrink session ran overtime. I see him every day and it’s still not enough.

I thought only director's assistants needed psychiatrists, not writers. Stefano laughs off the barb and takes a seat as Peggy sli out. The two men stare at each other but Stefano’s not remotel intimidated.
Do you see a shrink, Mr. Hitchcock? Hitch’s eyes follow a plume of cigar smoke curling up to ceiling...
No. His gaze remains pointedly fixed on the ceiling. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) I must say it boggles the mind to imagine what you and your “shrink” could possibly talk about daily.
The usual: sex. Rage. My mother. Hitchcock lowers his gaze, suddenly intrigued.
Alma sits with the Hitchcocks’ ACCOUNTANT who’s consultin ledger. She sits at her desk in the corner of the kitchen
There's still the federal income tax payments... the property taxes... Not to mention the absence of any salary while he’s actually making the film...
Stop waffling, Donald. Give it to me straight. (CONTINUED )
The Accountant takes off his glasses, plucking up the cou to look his favorite client in the eye.
Hitch wasn’t exaggerating. If the film's a flop, you’re going to have to sell the house. Alma digests this.
Where do you suggest we cut?
Anywhere you can.

Alma’s moved to the kitchen table and is sorting through accounts herself, the dogs at her feet. Her face is now properly filled with concern. Hitch enters, holding out some typed pages. Alma covers h worry. He puts the pages on the table next to her.
I got Joe Stefano to write out the first few scenes. Why don’t you take a look? Alma takes Stefano's pages and starts to read...Hitch goe the fridge and opens the door.
We're about to have dinner. You don’t need anything else. He shuts the door. Leans against the fridge door. Hitch w but she gives nothing away...until she off-handedly place the pages on the table...
Well? She doesn’t look up...
Hire him.

The door opens and Hitchs step outside. The Cadillac is waiting. Alma follows him out and makes a final adjustment to his
The only thing worse than a visit to the dentist is one to the censor.
Whatever you do, Alfred, don’t lose your temper.

The intimidating plaque for the MPAA’s “PRODUCTION CODE ADMINISTRATION OFFICE” on the wall. Stefano’s TITLE PAGE is tapped angrily by GEOFFREY SHURLO 70s, the much-feared administrator for the Motion Picture Production Code. He sits at the head of a big table with ASSISTANTS. Sitting opposite are Hitchcock, Peggy and sev silent PARAMOUNT EXECUTIVES.
The Code will absolutely not permit you to show a knife penetrating a woman's flesh.
I assure you, Geoffrey, my murders, are always models of taste and discretion.
Is there any improper suggestion of nudity in this murder scene in the shower?
She won't be nude. She’1l be wearing a shower cap. Shurlock makes a note. A man utterly devoid of any sense humor. (CONTINUED )

We might accept a shot from outside the bathroom window with Marion in silhouette above the shoulders -- provided the glass is frosted. Hitch greets the suggestion with barely concealed contemp Shurlock turns the page.
Then -- this scene with the toilet.
It’s completely necessary. Marion flushes evidence later found by her sister. It’s a clue to the girl’s disappearance.
No American movie has ever found it “necessary” to show a toilet, let alone to flush it. Hitch turns to Peggy and a Paramount Executive.
Perhaps we ought to shoot the film in France and use a bidet instead? No response from Shurlock’s end of the room. Peggy stares down at the table.

Mr. Hitchcock, if this office denies you a seal, and we're certainly heading in that direction, your movie will not be released in a single theater in this country. Will you be making jokes then? Hitchcock gives a slow but meaningful shrug. GEOFFREY SHURLOCK (CONT’D) Good. Now why don’t we go all the way back to page two...

boiling with rage as we hear the flurry of script pages - INT. PSYCHIATRIST’S OFFICE, BEVERLY HILLS - DAY Sunlight filters through sheer curtains revealing Hitchco trying his best to recline on an ANALYST’S COUCH. (CONTINUED )

Everyone in Hollywood resents me. I make them millions... and yet every year I sit at those dreadful award show dinners, waiting for them to say, just once, “You're good.” He looks around the luxurious office. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) They take sadistic pleasure in denying me that one little moment. ANALYST’S VOICE That must hurt.

Deeply. Hitch fumbles for a handkerchief and mops his brow. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) You'll have to excuse me, doctor. I’m not used to this... process... ANALYST’S VOICE Take your time. Now Hitch claws at his tie. It’s hot in here.

It’s just that, more and more lately, I’ve been having these... impulses. The analyst's MONTBLANC pen makes a note on a pad. We not that his hands are surprisingly coarse. ANALYST’S VOICE What kind of impulses? Finally Hitchcock is still. He stares up at the ceiling.
Strong ones.

A FRIDGE DOOR SNAPS OPEN to reveal Hitchcock's FACE in th darkness. He’s in his pajamas. His hand trembles next to stack of chicken breasts and moves to an upturned GRAPEFR HALF at the back of the shelf. (CONTINUED )

He pulls it out it to reveal a hidden stash of foie gras under the hollowed out grapefruit. He’s about to devour it when he catches sight of his DISTORTED REFLECTION in the chrome shelving. He backs away, disgusted at this monster before him, the light of the fridge illuminating his expression.

A door is quietly shut and locked. The bottom drawer of a filing cabinet is inched open. A hand rummages deep insid and teases out a bulging MANILA FOLDER. A hidden stash of some kind. The DESK LIGHT is switched on revealing HITCH. He careful extracts the contents of the folder and lays them onto th desk.

head_text.subj: A MASS OF PHOTOS OF ALL HIS BLONDE LEADING LADIES

text: A personal collection lovingly kept. He settles in to stu it, picking out his favorites, arranging them in order. They're all in the same pose, all with hair pinned up int perfect bun. He looks at each image with intensifying desire. He’s cre all of them. Every detail. But it’s no longer enough...

head_text.subj: THE ROW OF GLOSSY PERFECT BLONDES

text: INT. HITCHCOCK’S OFFICE, PARAMOUNT - SAME TIME A row of HANDSOME ACTOR HEADSHOTS on a table. HITCH glare the waiting ACTORS in the hallway through the blinds. He turns back to Peggy and Alma and pulls a face.
Send them all back to Glendale. Hitch returns to the table to ponder yet more headshots. Peggy shares a glance with Alma, then slides over RODDY MCDOWELL’S HEADSHOT.
The Lazar Office tells me he’s crazy to work with you. (CONTINUED )
Well, tell “Swifty” he shouldn’t have overexposed his client on television.
Unlike certain people we could mention. Hitch ignores the barb. Undeterred, Alma pushes her ace c a photo of ANTHONY PERKINS, radiating offbeat sensitivity teen idol looks.
Think of the duality he could bring to Norman. The rage lurking behind that little-boy-lost grin. The winsome charm he uses to keep from being found out.
Why, Alma, you’re not suggesting that Mr. Perkins is -- ? She raises her pinky finger just slightly. Alma nods with judgement.
Pondering... INT. HITCHCOCK’S OFFICE, PARAMOUNT - NEXT DAY Anthony Perkins now sits across from Hitchcock.
I can’t count how many times I’ve seen Strangers On a Train and Rope.

Well, Norman is the logical extension of the boys in those movies. Appealing, sensitive, suffering the terrible burden of being forced to pretend to be something he is not. Hitchcock's deeply-felt remark lands with Perkins.
My only worry is that playing Norman might cut too close to home.
How so? (CONTINUED )
Hitch’s calmness is strangely reassuring to the young actor...

I was incredibly close to my mother. So close I remember wishing my father would drop dead. And then when I was five, he did just that...He keeled over from a heart attack. (laughing nervously) You see I’ve been guilty my whole life, Mr. Hitchcock. Hitch is enthralled.
Try to remember this is all just make believe. Perkins wishes he could be more reassured...
Not to be prudish, but how far do you plan to push Norman’s relationship with his mother?
Further than you can possibly imagine. On Perkins uncertain expression -- what is he letting him in for?

Hitchcock’s RED SWEATING FACE as he grunts and heaves. He dressed in gardening gear, laboring in the full bloom of rose garden. Alma pushes a WHEELBARROW filled with manure She shovels the manure around the rosebushes.
I'm getting blisters just looking at you.
Stop grumbling. A bit of fresh air and exercise is exactly what you need. He holds his PRUNING SHEARS menacingly over a deep red Sydonie rose. (CONTINUED )
If I could get Grace Kelly to play the girl, they’d let me get away with anything.
Well you can’t. She's a princess now which makes her permanently unattainable. Hitchcock beheads the ROSE, muttering to himself.
And all the more desirable. His shears are now poised over a yellow specimen.
Lew suggested Deborah Kerr.
Too... Scottish. Hitchcock cuts it too and moves on to the stem of a perfe pink rose.

What about Janet Leigh? She’s always the ‘good girl’ but she did awfully well in Touch of Evil. Lew mentioned her name. Do you remember how you always remarked on her figure at the Wassermans' parties? As the shears hover on the stem, unsure whether to cut...

INT. CHASEN’S RESTAURANT - NIGHT THE SLENDER WAIST AND AMPLE BOSOM OF JANET LEIGH as she elegantly enters the dining room of Chasen’s. Hitch stands to greet her, his eyes follow her across the room in some private rapture.. Alma watches as Janet removes her glove and shakes Hitch’ hand...before he guides her to the spot to his left, acro from Alma. INT. CHASEN’S RESTAURANT - NIGHT Hitch finishes telling his story... (CONTINUED )
Of course the real secret of Mrs. Simpson's appeal to the Duke of Windsor was that she could make a toothpick feel like a cigar. He’s so deadpan... it takes a moment before she laughs.
You know, I’ve been so immersed in preparing to play Marion I'd almost forgotten how to laugh. Hitch summons the waiter with a snap.
Now, you must try the banana shortcake.
Nothing for me, thank you. I’m watching my figure. Alma watches all this with a fixed smile.
You’re not the only one. (to the waiter) We're fine, thank you. Hitchcock ignores Alma, gesturing to the waiter again.

Bring her the banana shortcake, George. In fact make it two large portions. He pointedly shifts to face Janet. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) So do tell me, how else have you’ve prepared to play Marion? Janet hesitates.

I’ve written a complete history for her...It seems silly, but it helps me. She turns to pull a LEATHER NOTEBOOK from her handbag, Hitch’s gaze locks onto her silken blonde hair, tied immaculately into the classic ‘Hitchcock bun’. (CONTINUED )
It doesn't sound silly at all. Tell me one of her deepest secrets. A quick look to Alma, as if to ask for permission before

She leads a double life. For instance, when she works at the Lowery office, she wears Tweed perfume. But, when she and Sam are together, she recklessly breaks out her one expensive bottle -- “My Sin” by Lanvin. She notices Alma’s expression.
But...I do have a concern or two. I’m an actress but I’m also a wife and mother first, so I’m wondering just how you’1l do that shower scene.
You and the Shurlock Office.

It’s just... I mean even if you shoot me from here -- (she indicates a spot just above her bosom) -- well it’s not as if my figure is boyish. Hitchcock looks down at her torso, as if noting it for th first time.

Allow me to put your mind at rest. Alma reacts as Hitch reaches over and gives Janet’s hand reassuring squeeze. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) May I show you some of Mr. Saul Bass’s marvellous story boards? Hitch pulls out his folio case and shows Janet the storyboards (which we don’t see).
I plan to shoot quick bits of film from various angles. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

Cut together, this montage will suggest nudity and violence but nothing will actually be shown. Janet studies them, deeply impressed. And relieved. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) And having you in the shower will make it all the more tit-illating --

If you’ll excuse me. Alma’s had enough. Janet’s smile falters as she watches A get up and head to the restroom. She’s unsure of what jus happened but Hitch carries on regardless, either entirely oblivious or not caring at all... INT. CHASEN’S RESTAURANT, LADIES ROOM - NIGHT Alma enters and looks in the mirror, quietly devastated. looks up to find another reflection in a mirror behind he
Alma is SUDDENLY TRANSFORMED into a Technicolor Hitchcock blonde. In a beautiful Edith Head gown, her skin is velve perfection, her hair blonde and impeccable.
Oh, come off it, old girl. A bitchy STUDIO HEAD’S WIFE snaps Alma out of her reverie joining her at the sink to powder her face.
Alma, dear, how lovely to see you.
Hello Lillian.

You're looking a little pale. No wonder with that thing your husband’s working on now. You can’t possibly approve. She's had a drink too many but the throwaway comment stil hits Alma hard. STUDIO HEAD WIFE (CONT’D) Why are you letting him do something so tasteless? (CONTINUED )
Don't upset yourself, darling. It's only a bloody movie.
Like in a Douglas Sirk movie. The same roses that are the ‘color’ of Janet Leigh. Alma hovers with her secateurs fo moment and then starts SNIPPING off their heads with a Caligula-like lack of mercy.

A vase of flowers, none of them pink, in the center of th table. Hitch STARES into a refrigerator filled with borin tasteless health-conscious food. Alma enters briskly and holds up a handwritten LIST.
I've made a list of places where we can tighten our belt. She places the list on the table.
It wouldn’t hurt for us all to learn the art of self restraint. Hitch goes over and picks it up, and reads.
The gardeners only once a week and weekends off for the driver? No. Absolutely not. We’ll find other places to cut.
There aren’t any other places. And furthermore, they’1l be no more shipments from Maxim’s either. We can’t afford it. She snatches the list out of his hand.
The foie gras at Chasen’s is more than adequate.
But those geese are from Barstow not Marseilles. (CONTINUED )
She turns back to him.

We all have to make our little sacrifices for the greater good, don’t we, Alfred? She leaves Hitch to resume contemplating the contents of fridge...but there’s nothing there to satisfy his growlin hunger. He SLAMS the fridge and --

Suddenly we’re moving through an empty living room, prowl just like in a Hitchcock movie as we hear CLUNKING, then over to catch a glimpse of Ed as he drags A WOMAN’S BODY, feet-first up the stairs. The clunking is from her head o the steps, which is wrapped in her dress. INT. ED GEIN’S HOUSE, BATHROOM - CONTINUOUS Ed approaches the shower curtain, then yanks it open with METALLIC SCREECH. He pushes the body into the tub. Pulls dress off her head and drops it on the floor.

Stay here. I’m going to get the knives. We pan to REVEAL HITCHCOCK standing in the corner. He loo terrified but completely enthralled -- he can’t resist creeping forward for a thorough inspection. Hitch’s POV a steps closer to the tub and glimpses the woman's blood- spattered WHITE BRA and GIRDLE. Suddenly -- FINGERS CLUTCH the rim of the tub.
Help me. Hitch recoils but she LURCHES UP and GRABS his throat.
Ed! Ed!
Hitchcock bolts upright in bed, face beaded with sweat in moonlight.
Ed... Ed...? (CONTINUED )
It takes a moment to get his bearings. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Am I making a mistake? Alma stirs in her bed. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) What if it’s another Vertigo?
Oh, shut up. Just get the first take under your belt you'll be fine. But Hitch isn’t looking convinced.
A sign posted outside the soundstage reads, “PRODUCTION REHEARSALS 9401. ABSOLUTELY NO VISITORS!” It only makes passing REPORTERS AND WORKERS more curious.
Inside, it’s a hive of quiet purposeful activity. A.D. HI GREEN escorts VERA MILES across the far side of the stage She's 30, a classic blonde porcelain beauty in the Grace Kelly mold.
I still can’t believe you cast Vera Miles as the sister. Hitch sits in his director's chair reading a copy of the London Times.
I’ve still got her under contract. I may as well get something out of it.
Rather a thankless role, don't you think?

For an utterly thankless girl. But he still watches VERA over the top of his newspaper a the A.D. leads her through the maze of hazardous cables a light stands towards the fitting room. She passes an actor in a HIGHWAY PATROLMAN’S UNIFORM tryi on various sunglasses with the prop master. (CONTINUED )
Shurlock’'s office called again. They want to know when you'll be making the changes to the script. Hitch gets up from his chair.
The more we frustrate them the more their interest will wane. He goes over to specify the correct sunglasses that shoul worn. The Cop puts on the MIRRORED shades. Hitch nods his approval.

CLOSE ON A RAIL OF SWIMSUITS. Alma browses through them carefully. They are all perfectly nice, if a little staid Her eyes suddenly catch a COLORFUL SWIMSUIT on the end of rail. It’s striking, even a little risque. She looks at t price tag. It’s insanely expensive. She turns to go... stops... then impulsively turns back a grabs it, heading into the changing room and closing the behind her.
light blasts through A TINY HOLE in the wall. An EYE positions itself in front of the peephole.
We hear the VOICES of two women quietly conversing on the other side.
Strains to get a better view.
We catch teasing glimpses of golden girl Vera Miles strip down to bra and panties.
HITCHCOCK'S EYEBALL fills the frame as he peers through t tiny hole. We reveal Vera with sharp, bohemian costumer R RIGGS, 27, who drapes taupe-colored fabric to Vera's contours. (CONTINUED )
Break it to me gently. Am I playing a lesbian librarian?
(re: the fabric) He chose it himself and had it imported from Paris. Vera laughs dryly at a WIG on a dummy head.
If I wear that, I’m going to look like George Washington.
Wait until you see the undergarments he picked out for you. Vera tosses off her shirt.

I just have to keep telling myself, one more picture and I'm free as a bird. She unhooks her bra and crosses to hang it on a hook righ near the HOLE where we just saw Hitchcock’s eye. His eye gone, only darkness from the other side. Vera feels a chi and instinctively covers her breasts with her arm.
Is there a fan blowing somewhere? Rita returns with a punitive bra and girdle.
Wow. The old man really is unhappy with me, isn’t he? EXT. JANET’S DRESSING ROOM, UNIVERSAL REVUE - DAY Hitch knocks at the door.
Are you decent my dear? JANET steps out dressed in a crisp, sexy white shirt and pencil skirt. She does a twirl for him. The effect is stunning. Even the stagehands stop to watch.
Am I alright? (CONTINUED )
His picks a tiny piece of lint on her sleeve.
Perfect. As he escorts her onto the soundstage, Tony comes up to g them.
I want to thank you again for this opportunity, Mr. Hitchcock.

It's just “Hitch”, Tony. Hold the cock. Janet caught that -- she’s clearly amused. Tony gives her gracious peck on the cheek. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Look at you two. America’s favorite boy and girl nextdoor... Janet flicks a glance back at Hitch.

And we're about to move to a whole new neighborhood. Already, Tony can’t help feel a little excluded from Hitc and Janet’s little clique. Hitch ushers them across the soundstage where the crew are assembling.
Morning Janet. Morning Tony. Vera Miles marches up in her frumpy tweed suit and wig.
“Thanks” for the wardrobe, Hitch.
(already moving past her) That’s hand-woven imported camel hair from Rodier. Don’t you approve?
You're the genius. She checkmates him with a ravishing smile.
One thing, though. My script is missing the last ten pages. (CONTINUED )
Everyone's is. Until Alma finishes the revisions. Now hurry along, Vera. You're just in time for the oath.

The what? He steers her towards a line of laughing CREW MEMBERS for a circle with the rest of the cast. He takes Janet by the hand, placing her right next to him officiously raises his right hand. The cast and crew duly follow suit, all except for Vera.
I solemnly promise...
I solemnly promise...
(ignoring Vera’s sarcasm) That I will not divulge the plot nor the many secrets of Psycho...
That I will not divulge the plot nor the many secrets of Psycho... WE SEE VERA’S CROSSED FINGERS BEHIND HER BACK Then tilt up to Janet’s look of mock disapproval. Vera po her tongue out.

To friends, relatives, trade reporters or columnists -- not even to outgoing President Dwight D. Eisenhower, God bless him. Everyone cracks up, but Hitchcock’s only interested in th reaction of his new blonde, standing in pride of place, r beside him.
ALMA sits at the desk typing away at the revisions for “Psycho.” -- we see the title page. A tiny solitary figure with nothing for company but a vas wilting flowers... (CONTINUED )

She pauses, takes off her glasses and pushes aside her corrections, suddenly fed up with the all the work. She looks out at the swimming pool, sparkling in the sunlight... then turns to the expensive-looking SHOPPING half-open on the side... We hear a LOUD SPLASH --

As Alma plunges into the water wearing her striking new swimsuit. She breaks into a front crawl. Her strokes are vigorous, surprisingly so. She drives the length of the pool, her arms slashing thro the water with increasing speed, her feet kicking out wit rising intensity... harder and harder... faster and faste
Hitch guides Janet and Tony across the sound stage to the of Norman’s parlor.
Now, Hitch, explain to me why I’m watching Marion undress?
I feel like I should take offense at that. She and Tony laugh. Hitch’s eyes light up at this display mischief from her.
I don’t know...Perhaps as a boy, Norman secretly watched his mother preparing for her nightly bath.
Maybe there was a transom over the bathroom door?
Yes -- one he could access with a chair so long as he was stealthy.
Well, a boy’s first glimpse of a naked woman is usually his mother. (CONTINUED )
So...I'm reliving the past, repeating a ritual with Marion?
You're the actor. You figure it out. Tony flinches at Hitch’s brusque response. They arrive at the set wall, where Hitch removes a painti to reveal the PEEPHOLE.
Hitch, I have a question. Why is the hole much larger on this side?

All the better to see you at the greatest possible angle my dear... Janet simply steps up and presses her face to the hole. H studies her profile, quietly thrilled at her curiosity. T hangs back, watching Hitch watching her...
Wow. You really do your research, don't you?

It’s just my Jesuit work ethic. He takes a quick peek through the hole now too...then put the painting carefully back into place over it. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (PRE-LAP) (CONT’D) The truth is... I’m only happy when I’m working... INT. PSYCHIATRIST’S OFFICE, BEVERLY HILLS - DAY Hitch lies on his Analyst’s couch.

»+. and if I’m not working then I’m nothing. I’m not even a person. I’m just a collection of molecules. A useless cylinder of ugly flesh. The Analyst circles one of his notes on a pad with his Montblanc. Again, we notice how rough-hewn his hands are. (CONTINUED )
ANALYST’S VOICE (0.S.) What about your mother? Let’s go back to her.
My mother? Yes. Hitch looks over at the unseen analyst and considers him.

She was an extraordinary person. She exposed me to Ibsen, Strindberg, Shaw. She hoped I would go into engineering -- carry a lunch pail, gold watch at fifty. ANALYST’S VOICE (0.S.) She didn't approve of your career?

To her, movie people were akin to thieves and prostitutes. He turns back to look out the window. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) If I misbehaved, she'd make me stand at the foot of her bed and discuss how I planned to become a better boy. The Analyst leans forward and we see his dirty, worn-down fingernails. ANALYST’S VOICE (0.S.) Have you ever considered that your deep desire to gain the approval of your industry represents a textbook case of transference? (then) The Oscar is your mother.
It’s ED GEIN. In his Sunday best, his shovel leaning agai the mahogany-paneled wall in the background.
You're a fine one to talk.
Hitchcock leads Janet to a row of brassieres, all laid ou for inspection. They are all white with recognizable labe Berlei, Triumph, Marks & Spencer. He picks out one of the (CONTINUED )
You will be wearing a white bra like this for the opening scene on the bed. And then after you’ve stolen the money... They move on to a second row of brassieres - all dark.
I switch to one of these. He nods, correct. She moves over to a mannequin displayin the iconic jet black brassiere.
Are you sure you don’t want to look at something a little more elegant?

(sharp) No. They have to look like they were bought at Sears and Roebuck. I want every woman in the audience to look up at Janet having sex with John Gavin and think, ‘that could be me’. Janet reads the label. It’s “Maidenform.”
This is the brand I wear. Hitch digests the information and turns to Rita.
We're ready for a fitting. As Rita starts to measure Janet’s chest, Hitchcock lifts hands and ‘frames’ her...
We travel across the rooftops of downtown Phoenix and finally, through the heat, pick out a certain hotel window...
Close on Hitchcock's FRAMING HANDS as they now travel up an open window with blinds half down...
We go under the blinds and match dissolve into the room itself...
HITCHCOCK'S HANDS have now become THE CAMERA, recording t scene already underway and now watched by HITCHCOCK, his DIRECTOR OF PHOTOGRAPHY and CREW from across the stage...

We pan over and discover John and Janet on the bed. ...the camera moves to Janet and John making out on the b It’s serious stuff. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) She'll be wearing only her undergarments and a large glow of satisfaction... JANET smiles up at John contentedly.
watching from his directing chair. Peggy stands next to h ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Cut.
Good luck getting this one past the censor.
Alma drives the gleaming black Cadillac through the UNIVE GATES and pulls up to the production office outside the stage.

Alma collects the script pages off the front seat and wal into the production office just missing Whit as he stroll back towards the writers building with a couple of pretty SECRETARIES. Whit pauses when he spots the Hitchcocks’ CADILLAC.
You girls go on ahead. The PRETTIEST ONE stops to make Whit light her cigarette before catching up with the others.
Peggy reads the final pages while Alma inspects the production boards.
If you ask me, the credits should read “Screenplay by Joseph Stefano and Alma Reville.”
The people who matter know. That’s all that counts. As she makes a few more changes to the schedule. Alma tur to Peggy whose face tightens as she continues reading. Clearly it’s strong stuff.
I'd hate to see Shurlock’s face when he reads this. She puts the pages down.
Alma, you always know the answer. Is this really going to work? A candid moment between the two women... but Alma doesn’t answer, just leaves.
Alma emerges into the sunshine and looks across at the soundstage, wondering whether she should go over there...
Hello, stranger. She turns to see Whit leaning against the Cadillac.
Whit.
Where have you been hiding yourself?
I’ve been doing the revisions on... She points to the PSYCHO HOUSE on the ridge. (CONTINUED )
Psycho. (then) And how is the old boy?
In a state of unbridled ecstacy now that he’s back on the set.
And you? How are you?
Not bad. I’ve got eight hundred words to do for Reader's Digest on what it’s like to be married to a man obsessed by murder. He looks at her a moment.

I’ve got a better idea. He steps closer. WHITFIELD COOK (CONT’D) Why don’t we drive out to Santa Barbara? We'll have Emilio fry up those juicy steaks we like at El Encanto. He playfully tugs at her sleeve. WHITFIELD COOK (CONT’D) No shoptalk ... No silly magazine articles...just a wonderful meal... Alma’s expression gives away nothing as we pan over to th WINDOW of the production office and notice the tell-tale in the blinds.
Hitch looks out at Whit and Alma through the window, just like he did with the other couple earlier. Except this li interaction is far from dull.
We're ready for you on the set, Mr. Hitchcock.
I'll be right there. (CONTINUED )
But Hitch doesn’t move.
Mr. Hitchcock?
ALMA enters the silent, empty house smiling to herself. S walks through to -
- and puts the grocery bags down on the counter. She list The house is eerily quiet, until, from behind --
Was there a line at the market? Alma looks up, but doesn’t turn round, well used to Hitch cryptic ways.
No. Actually, I'm back sooner than I expected. She puts on an apron and gets to work, preparing dinner.
Would you like a cocktail? He heads for the liquor cabinet.
No. (he starts to head off) And you shouldn't either. Hitchcock stops. Pulls out a CELERY STICK from one of the bags and bites it.
Those haven't been washed yet.

(chewing) I don’t care. (then) I was filming all day with John Gavin -- a good-looking chap but, really, plywood is more expressive. His love scene with Janet may be most horrifying thing in the picture. (CONTINUED )
He takes another BITE, searching her face for some tell-t sign of guilt. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Even your friend Whitfield Cook would be better in the scene.
You should tell Whit that. He'd be flattered. She gets to work preparing a salad. Hitch studies the bac her tiny, vulnerable neck, the delicate sinews and muscle they rise and flex.
Hitch arranges his pillows and settles into bed while Alm finishes getting ready.

Maybe I was too dismissive about your friend Whitfield’s book. Perhaps he and Elizabeth could come over this weekend and he can walk me through it. Alma’s radar activates but Hitch continues oh-so- nonchalantly.

Lovely woman, Elizabeth... He carefully folds his blanket as if wrapping a murder victim. She’s not exactly sure what he’s implying but she knows she doesn’t like it. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) I was hoping you could come by the set tomorrow.
I'll see how my day shapes up. She turns onto her side away from him. Pulls the blankets around her, her eyes still WIDE OPEN.
You think you can get away with it but you can’t... Alma’s eyes become HITCHCOCK'S EYES, staring ahead intent
.»+. You think they can’t tell... but they can. They know. It’s all closing in on you. The noose is tightening... As he continues, we pull back and see:

Janet emotes for Hitchcock’s CAMERA while “driving” a PAR CAR, being rocked by STAGE HANDS. Peggy and other CREW time and mark the takes. ELECTRICIAN AND GAFFERS turn mounted lamps that rake across Janet's worried face like car headlights. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) You could return the money secretly, but what would be the point? He wipes his brow, getting more intense...

You, Marion Crane. The prim and proper girl who’s always been so tight and respectable. So perfect and untouchable. Well, they know all about your dirty little secret, don’t they? Your messy, sticky lunchtime trysts. Yes, your boss Mr. Lowery could even smell the sex on you-- SUDDENLY THE REAR SCREEN film breaks and a frame burns. It's a good thing because Janet is starting to look a lit uncomfortable -- was that meant to be funny? As technicia yell and hustle, Hitchcock turns to Peggy -- ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Circle that.
As Janet gets changed, Vera hangs up her frumpy coat on a rack, looking over a little enviously at Janet’s good girl/bad girl underwear hanging nearby.
Have you talked to him much about your personal life? (CONTINUED )
Not really...

I'd keep it that way if I were you. (Off Janet’s look) He starts by choosing your hairstyle and clothes and then he wants to choose your friends and decide how many children you should have. Janet finds this a little hard to believe. Vera leans in, lowering her voice.
That poor, tortured soul Jimmy Stewart played in Vertigo? That's Hitch, only younger, slimmer and better-looking. That may well be true but it doesn’t bother Janet.

Compared to Orson Welles, he’s a sweetheart. They both turn, sensing something -- and see HITCHCOCK'S DISTINCTIVE SHADOW PROFILE in the hallway. The shadow lingers, then recedes like in a scary ghost story.
(whispers) See? He's always watching. They laugh nervously.

Alma comes in from her gardening, and settles on the sofa with a cup of tea, a circled copy of TV Guide next to her On television -- the 1950 Hitchcock classic Stage Fright. The credits come up: “Screenplay by Whitfield Cook, Adaptation by Alma Reville.” Alma watches, thrilled at the sight of her name and Whit’ together.
The words “DIRECTED BY ALFRED HITCHCOCK” overwhelm the sm screen. Alms puts down her fork, no longer hungry.
ALMA heads back to the kitchen, only to pause at the open door to Hitch’s study -- there’s something on the desk.

Hitch’s personal collection. Alma enters and starts to go through them. Each photo is turned over a little more rou than the last. It’s hard to tell whether she’s more angry the photos or the fact that they’ve been deliberately lef for her to find... Alma takes off an earring, picks up the phone and starts dial...
As the crew prepares the car set to go again, Hitch strid over to PEGGY who’s dialing a phone.
What’s the hold up?
It’s still engaged. He takes the phone himself just as Vera Miles emerges fro her dressing room, script in hand.
Hitch, I’m stuck on Lila’s first scene. I don’t know how strongly I should confront Sam and the detective and I --

(acidly) Fake it. He turns his back on her and dials. The ENGAGED TONE blar in his ear. His eyes narrow at some crew members fussing bits of LIGHT and SOUND EQUIPMENT. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Does it really require two men to carry a light stand?
I'll take care of it right away, Mr. Hitchcock. (CONTINUED )
He rushes off to fix it. Off Peggy’s questioning look.
It's different when their pay is coming out of your own pocket. He raps the receiver button, more intensely this time, an redials.
But Alma’s still on the phone to Whit, basking in his cha Her feet are up. There’s a drink in her hand.
Well, I think that sounds like a fabulous idea. We’ll have a late lunch. I’1l1 make the reservation for one thirty.
What would I do without you?
Till then, bye. She hangs up, toying with her earring, feeling better alr when the PHONE rings again very quickly. She picks up wit even thinking --
(laughing) What did you forget now?
Pudgy fingers clench the coiled PHONE CORD as we move up Hitch’s face. He’s silent as a burglar, not even daring t breathe...
Whit? Is that you? The blood drains from Hitch’s face as he very slowly and carefully replaces the receiver. His mind starts to spin. He’s got to get out of there...
Hitch lurches towards the production office, starting to sweat, but his path is blocked by GRIPS laying cables. Th set is suddenly a cacophony of noise and chaos. A PR FLACK appears -- (CONTINUED )

Mr. Hitchcock, every press outlet is driving us crazy for photos -- Hitch brushes past him to find another route but more gri are moving a ladder. He turns, kicks a platter of healthy snacks out of the way, only for an ARCLIGHT to swivel in face and blind him.
Are you okay? You’ve gone very pale. Peggy's face suddenly comes into focus.
Stop trailing me like a puppy dog and get me something long, cool and wet.
It's not even three.
Give me the key! He snatches it and pushes past her, leaving her flat.
HITCH exits the soundstage doors, only to find the humorl face of BARNEY BALABAN blocking his office door.
Hello, Hitch. How’s the picture? I’m hearing interesting things...
It’s a wonder you can hear anything over the noise coming from the Shurlock office. Balaban offers up his handkerchief. Hitchcock waves it aw even though he’s now covered in sweat.
I shouldn’t be in a position of just hearing things, Hitch. It’s time you showed me some footage.
Why? (CONTINUED )
To see if you’re making a picture Paramount can actually release.
As you well know, Barney, my contract guarantees me final cut.
Your contract also says Paramount isn't required to distribute any film that could cause us embarrassment.

Unlike the last five Martin and Lewis pictures you’re all so proud of. He slams the door in Balaban’s startled face. INT. HITCHCOCK’S OFFICE, UNIVERSAL REVUE - CONTINUOUS Hitchcock loosens his collar and catches a glimpse of him in a mirror. He’s unraveling and it shows.
I demand to see some footage, Hitch. Hitch lowers the window blinds over Balaban’s face and fumbles for the phone.

Connect me to Maxim’s of Paris. He takes the key and opens the liquor cabinet ignoring th INSISTENT KNOCKING at the door -- ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) (on phone) Yes, it’s Alfred Hitchcock in Hollywood, California, Jean-Claude. I need three pounds of foie gras sent on the next flight out. (then) That’s correct. Three. He pours himself five fingers of scotch.
A majestic view of the coastline as Whitfield Cook's Crea MERCEDES 190CL, zooms along, top down. Alma wears white- rimmed sunglasses and a head scarf. (CONTINUED )
Whitfield, in true Hitchcock leading man style, has the perfect amount of wind blowing through his hair.
Those steaks haven’t changed at all, have they?
It's so nice not to have to take care of someone, even if it's just for an hour or two. She takes in the sparkling scenery whipping past.
Whit, where are we going? You still haven’t told me.
I have a little surprise.

A surprise. How fun. Whit just smiles as he jams the acceleration and the car ROARS off down the highway. EXT. HITCHCOCK’S OFFICE, UNIVERSAL REVUE - DAY Hitch stands in the parking lot tapping his foot impatien near the parked Ford Fairlaine police car used in ‘PSYCHO Janet watches him, sitting behind the wheel of her VOLKSW BEETLE. After a moment she toots her horn and drives up.
What happened to your driver?
I've been asking myself the same thing. She smiles.
I can give you a ride if you want. Hitchcock raises an eyebrow at the tiny car, and then, wi great effort inches his massive frame through the open do
Did you know Adolf Hitler sketched the design for this car on Ferdinand Porsche's cocktail napkin in a Berlin beer garden?
I didn’t. She turns to see Hitch wedged uncomfortably into his seat

It’s only now that I truly appreciate just how diabolical Herr Hitler was. She notices him eyeing the half-eaten bag of CANDY CORN o the dashboard (the kind Norman Bates enjoys throughout “Psycho”.) ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) May I?
Help yourself. (letting him in on it) I pinched them from Tony’s dressing room. He takes one and chews it curiously.
So this is what they eat at the drive- ins... He takes the whole bag and sets to work, popping them in after the other.
I thought you only ate Fauchon chocolate.
Needs must when the devil drives, my dear. He’s so deadpan but now there’s no way to tell if he’s jo or not. She puts the car into gear, sensing his despair.
(CONTINUED )
nesting in the sand. Alma and Whit sit out watching the s The water laps over their toes.
I don’t mind that he uses his obsession to fuel his art. I just don’t like it when he uses it against me.
He's like any great artist. Impossible to live with but worth the effort. (he throws a rock into the sea) Van Gogh wasn’t exactly a walk in the park either.

Did you know when we started out I was his boss? He didn’t even dare ask me out until he’d worked his way up to assistant director. Whit watches as she picks up some sand, lets it run throu her fingers...
What do you think of that place over there? He nods to a SMALL BEACH HOUSE up the way.
Looks nice. Terrific location. Why?
It's mine. She looks at him askance. Is he joking?
I just saw Elizabeth. Why on earth didn't she tell me?
She doesn't know about it.
The sun is setting on the Hitchcocks’ driveway. The VW pu to a stop in front of the front door.
(CONTINUED )
Janet looks over -- decides to risk it.
So what did happen between you and Vera?

I was going to make her star. But she chose the life of a housewife. He stops chewing. We push in as his features turn reflect ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) I cast her as the lead in Vertigo. Then two weeks before filming she told me was pregnant. He screws up the empty bag of candy and looks over at Jan Then, almost like a child -- ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Why do they do it? Why do they always betray me?
As she looks across and sees the lonely abandoned little just sitting there...
Alma enters the beach house cautiously and looks around. is old and falling apart with only a few functional furnishings.
I'm just leasing it for the offseason. A place to get away from the wife and kid and write.
Very Bohemian.
You might find that room interesting. Alma looks. The door is partially open -- she sees the on conspicuously new item of furniture. A double bed.
Whit. I hope you haven’t got the wrong idea. (CONTINUED )
He gives her a rakish grin, then pushes the door open fur to reveal the deck beyond.
Sit on a table facing each other.

If you were serious about helping me adapt my book, I thought it would be the perfect hideaway. She lets this sink in, entranced by the incredible view a the crashing surf. Then, she steps out onto the deck and up to one of the typewriters. Gives the key an approving TAP.
Hitch enters the empty house at dusk. The dogs greet him. listens a moment... then walks through to the study.

Hitch pours himself a brandy and downs it in one. He goes pour himself a second, when he notices something on the d It’s his collection of PHOTOS by the TELEPHONE. They’re a neatly stacked. With a SINGLE GOLD EARRING on top.

Hitch lies in bed, his thoughts racing as he waits for Al to come home. Finally, the sound of the car comes up the driveway. He turns onto his side and pulls up the blankets, listeni to the sound of the front door ... and Alma’s footsteps d the hall. She quietly slips into the bathroom and shuts the door be turning the light on. He watches her shadow through the s of light at the bottom of door. When the bathroom light switches off again Hitch hurriedl closes his eyes. (CONTINUED )
Alma emerges in her nightgown and stops at his bedside, peering down on him. She's not completely sure that he's actually awake, but she suspects.

Hitch eases himself up and looms over Alma to make sure s is safely asleep. He silently picks up her HANDBAG and takes it to the wind Using the moonlight he searches its contents. Car keys. Lipstick. Purse. And the first few pages of a story outline: "TAXI TO DUBROVNIK” The pages vibrate in his hand as his gaze lowers to revea the rest of the TITLE PAGE: “STORY TREATMENT BY WHITFIELD COOK & ALMA REVILLE.”

A GLISTENING MOUND OF FOIE GRAS spooned into Hitchcock’s mouth straight from the MAXIM’S OF PARIS tin. Hitch stand the glare of the open fridge, a beast feeding in its cave shoving in mouthful after mouthful. It’s almost pornograp in its indulgence. GEIN steps out of the shadows and puts a comforting hand Hitch’s shoulder. We hear the civilized CLINK of cutlery against china...
Hitch and Alma sit at the table having lunch. Alma eats a pork chop while Hitch defiantly nibbles at his healthy sa He has a nice big glass of red wine which Alma ignores.
So I read your finished treatment. “Taxi to -- " Where was it?
Dubrovnik.
That's it. Dubrovnik. Care to hear my opinion?
Yes. Naturally. (CONTINUED )
There’s no other way of saying it. It’s stillborn. Dead in the water. Alma blinks, unable to hide her shock.
How so?

(with mock compassion) The plot’s a muddle. Some of the jokes are awfully like things we already did better hundreds of years ago in The Lady Vanishes. And your villain is weak. But the biggest failure is the relationship between the hero and heroine. He picks up a radish and bites into it. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) If you weren’t so smitten with your friend Whitfield cook you'd probably see that. Alma is entirely stunned. Hitchcock has delivered the kil blow he intended. He gets up and goes over to the garden door. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Women never really care to face the truth when their hearts are involved, do they? As he steps out into the garden --
How would you know what really goes on between a man and a woman?
Hitch searches his pockets for his lighter but can’t find His annoyance only increases when he notices the SCATTERE LEAVES ‘contaminating’ the surface of the pool.
Look at this mess. He grabs the net and starts scooping them out. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Bloody belt-tightening. (CONTINUED )
He can’t get the net into the inflow filter so he gets do on his hands and knees and starts PULLING OUT the leaves his hands.
watches from the window... then turns away.
Pulls out handful after handful of wet leaves, clawing aw at them like a madman...

head_text.subj: A TEMPERATURE DIAL INCHES INTO THE RED

text: Stage hands and engineers test a row of HOT WATER TANKS installed on the set. WE FOLLOW the sound of rushing water through a PIPE as it snakes across the set floor and passes through a fake wal
Unleashing a stream of STEAMING HOT WATER. The SET HAND g the thumbs up.
Tell the boss we’re ready.
Peggy and A.D. Hilton Green exchange a glance as Hitchcoc paces up and down in the corridor, eager to get to work.

What’s the hold-up? Call time was two hours ago. Peggy nervously knocks on Janet's door and peers inside - INT. JANET LEIGH’S DRESSING ROOM - DAY Rita Riggs is hard at work molding MOLESKIN PATCHES to Janet's nipples.
And you're sure this moleskin will stay put?
Mr. Hitchcock promised. (CONTINUED )
Neither woman looks convinced but they proceed with blind faith.
It better. I’m going to be taking a shower all week. As Janet slips on her robe, a MOLESKIN TRIANGLE PLOPS ont the floor. Rita and Janet share a worried look.
Alma sits at her typewriter while Whit stares off, lookin little uncertain.
Forget what Hitch said. He’s just feeling his age. He’ll come around.
But he’s right. It does need more feeling. Alma ponders the problem. Finally --
So why don’t we put some in? She gets to her feet and starts to pace...
All we need is a better catalyst. Some innocuous little trigger to release all that underlying desire. The soothing sound of the ocean gives way to the relentle HISS of SHOWER WATER --
Janet nervously removes her bathrobe and heads toward the MOCK SHOWER STALL.

Good morning. He takes her hand and guides her into position. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) As I explained earlier, this scene will be made up of many shots from Mr. Bass’s boards. A series of looks - actions... (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Well, you’re the professional. You’1l know how to do it. Around them, the crew frantically finalize the CAMERA and LIGHT SETUPS. MALE CREW MEMBERS look uncomfortable and excited by the unprecedented sight of a virtually nude mo star. Saul Bass comes over with his boards and Hitch and he dis the planned shot a moment.
Tony’s stunt double is ready.

Ah. There’s our murderess. Into frame steps Anthony Perkins' FEMALE STUNT DOUBLE, MA wearing a gingham dress, silver wig and BLACK MAKEUP TO M HER FACE. She wields a large PROP KNIFE and almost blocks view of Janet in the white-tiled stall. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) (to Janet) Are you ready for our little bloodbath?
My mother always said, “Have confidence in yourself and you can lick anything.” Hitchcock takes Janet’s hand, and with tremendous sinceri

My mother used to say the same thing. (then) Let's go for a take. Quiet everyone. Over and over, Margo attacks with the knife and Janet tri deflecting the blows but both women are timid and Janet i clearly guarding her modesty and covering her body. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Cut. More intensely. Let’s go again. Margo's KNIFE comes at Janet uncertainly and every which Naked and exposed, Janet defends against the knife blows they come at her but Margo’s still pulling her punches-- ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) No. More angry. You are possessed with unbridled homicidal rage. (leaping up) Cut. Cut camera. (CONTINUED )

He charges over to Margo to demonstrate the savage stabbi gesture he demands. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Does no one understand what I’m trying to accomplish here? I’m older than anyone on this stage and I’m still standing. Everyone falls silent, unsure how to respond. Hitchcock H OUT HIS HAND. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Give me the knife. Margo places the knife in Hitchcock’s palm. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Props. Bring in more blood. A FEMALE MAKEUP ASSISTANT squirts more CHOCOLATE SYRUP “blood” onto Janet from a PLASTIC BOTTLE OF BOSCO. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Roll camera. As the scene is marked, we see Hitchcock’s anxiety. There NO SOUND except Hitchcock's ragged breathing.
Ready, sir. Hitchcock nods. The camera whirs. Hitchcock hoists the kn into the air with terrifyingly convincing power and malevolence.

head_text.subj: THE SHOWER CURTAIN GETS YANKED BACK --

text: We see in the shower from Hitchcock’s POV not Janet but GEOFFREY SHURLOCK. Hitchcock SLASHES the censor a killer that sends him reeling.
