text: Shurlock is replaced by BARNEY BALABAN. Hitchcock stabs h with unleashed fury and hate.

head_text.subj: THE SHOWER CURTAIN GETS YANKED BACK AGAIN --

text: WHIT turns, he’s naked and smiling. Hitch plunges the kni into his back, and he drops, revealing ALMA, arms around waist.

We're back in the real moment -- JANET LEIGH SCREAMING as gives the ‘performance’ of a lifetime. Hitchcock stops stabbing. His heart pounds. He’s soaked w sweat. The only sound is the drip-drip-drip of the shower
As he realizes EVERYONE is staring at him. He straightens tie, attempting to regain some semblance of control.

Print. We’ve got it. He exits quickly. Rita escorts the shaken and exhausted Janet off set, pass Vera who’s witnessed the whole thing. She’s wearing a bathrobe. Janet gives her a look as if to say ‘Now I understand.’ INT. HITCHCOCK’S OFFICE - UNIVERSAL REVUE - CONTINUOUS Hitch shuts his office door and leans back against it. He closes his eyes, nauseated and dizzy. He doesn’t even nee open them to know who’s there, waiting for him.
Not now, Ed. It’s really not a good time. He staggers towards the water cooler, fumbling for a cup. Ed steps forward and pours him some water, pats his shoul

You just can’t keep this stuff bottled up. But before Hitch can drink it he crashes to the floor. EXT. HITCHCOCK’S OFFICE - UNIVERSAL REVUE - SAME TIME Peggy and Perkins to react to the noise... HITCHCOCK’S OFFICE - UNIVERSAL REVUE - SAME TIME They come through the door to see Hitch lying on the floo He looks like he’s dead.
Oh God... (CONTINUED )
Peggy rushes forward to help. Perkins just stands and sta as if paralysed in some Freudian nightmare.
starts to ring.
It is inside the beach house, and partially drowned out b the sound of the crashing waves. Alma and Whit are on the deck, acting out the scene as they write, too engrossed t notice.
What if Helen and Michael try and get into the cab at the same time?
Even better, what if they reached for the cab door at exactly the same time? Alma demonstrates so that their hands touch.
That way, we could start close on the hands... (tracking the movement) +. and then tilt up to the eyes. They stare into each other’s eyes, lips just inches apart
That feels better already. Finally, the phone intrudes.
Are you going to get that? With some effort, Whit goes inside and picks it up.

Hullo?... Yes... Hold on. He comes outside, holding out the receiver for Alma. WHITFIELD COOK (CONT’D) It’s for you. INT. HITCHCOCK’S OFFICE, UNIVERSAL REVUE - DAY Peggy grips the phone, her face full of concern. (CONTINUED )

I know you told me only to call in an emergency, but I’m not sure how else to describe this. Hitch lies slumped on the floor. A compress over his forehead. His head lolls to one side as he slips in and o of consciousness... FADE TO BLACK.

Disarray on the set. MARTIN BALSAM watches as SAUL BASS, cameraman JACK RUSSEL and A.D. HILTON GREEN argue about the best way to proceed with the staircase sequence. Hitch is conspicuous by his absence. As they bicker we find Tony Perkins off to one side, sitt in his Mrs. Bates costume, unable to cope. He puts the wi back on his head. There, that feels better... Balsam’s finally had it with all the arguing. He walks of past Peggy who’s arriving with the PHONE.
It's official. The inmates are running the asylum. Peggy hands Hilton the phone.
Hilton. I have Mr. Hitchcock for you. She gives him a warning look. “Watch out. He’s in a terri mood.” He waves away her concern. It can’t be that bad.
Hey there, Hitch. We’re still working on it. (looking over at the continuing argument) Everyone misses you.
Hitch, in bed and sick as a dog, has the script, notes an boards on a bed tray. The phone receiver is pressed to hi ears. (CONTINUED )
I've told Peggy and now I'm going to tell you. You have to get this sequence shot today. What’s the hold up?
We tried it ten different ways and it looks terrible. Why don’t we use inserts?
No. It has to be a high angle. You'll tip off the big surprise! Just get the process shot. Hitch slams down the phone.
Still clutching the phone, a little nonplussed. Peggy giv him a look: “What did I tell you.”
Alma removes the phone from Hitch’s grasp. Touches his forehead.
No more phone calls. You're burning up.
Burning up our money. We're two days behind and I’m stuck in bed. Hitch swings his legs out of the bed.
Where do you think you’re going?
To the set. We can’t afford to lose any more time. Two more days of this and the whole production goes under. He shakily tries to get to his feet.
You stay in bed. I'11 deal with it.
I’d hate to take you away from your writing partner. (CONTINUED )
She pushes him back against the pillows. He’s too weak to resist.
Under the blankets. Now.

Crew members sit around eating donuts. Assistant director Hilton Green and cameraman Jack Russell are still arguing over the mechanics of the shot with more crew members joi in. It’s near pandemonium. Then Alma steps in the door, and everything stops. Every member snaps to attention as Alma passes by. It's like th school principal arriving after the substitute teacher ha lost control.

Don't stop work because of me. I’m only here as one of the two people paying your salaries. Alma takes a seat in Hitch's DIRECTOR'S chair. As her eye dart around the set, it's clear that she IS TAKING EVERYT IN. Peggy flanks her.
Scene?
One seventy three.
Storyboards? Peggy hands the boards to Alma. She and Hilton quickly re the boards.
Start with the overhead. We'll cut before the fall. Then we’ll put Martin ina chair under the camera. Hilton looks at Russell. Perfect. He sets ANTHONY PERKINS his dress into place.
(to the cameraman) And that lens should be a thirty-five. Peggy mouths Alma a silent “THANK YOU” for restoring orde
Hitchcock lies in bed, tossing and turning, the fever onl making his thoughts darker and more obsessive.

You forgot to look in the bathroom. Hitch notices the SHADOWY FIGURE standing at the end of h bed. ED GEIN (CONT’D) A man like you... Missing the vital clue like that... He blearily sits up and sees Gein’s impassive rustic face
What do you mean? Gein steps over to the bathroom and pushes open the door.
My mother always said if you’re going to do a job, do it right.
Hitchcock enters the immaculate white and chrome room and inspects it... but nothing seems out of place.
Check the floor. He looks down but again, nothing. ED GEIN (CONT’D) Closer. Hitch gets down on his hands and knees. He runs his fingertips across the smooth white tiles. They start to collect --
Sprinkled all over the floor. ED GEIN (CONT’D) You still think they’re just writing together? Hitchcock’s face hardens. His lip trembles. (CONTINUED )

ED GEIN (CONT’D) So what are you going to do about it? Hitch gets up, opens the medicine cabinet and takes out a BOTTLE OF BAYER ASPIRIN. He empties the tablets into the sink and very carefully, sweeps the SAND into the aspirin bottle. He caps it, slip into his robe pocket and turns off the light.
Alma spots the towering figure of Balaban stride onto the stage accompanied by a MAN in a cardigan.
Barney. He sees her and bristles, clearly surprised to see her th
Alma. Alma takes in Balaban’s companion, and the viewfinder rou his neck.
You know David Kirkpatrick. He’s working on Jerry Lewis’ next picture. She does. They nod politely -- then stand there.
So he’s free to help... (a sly smile) if you need it... Silence. Just the bustle of crew members in the backgroun
That won’t be necessary.

But you’re nearly three days behind. He takes a step towards Hitch’s empty chair, but Alma mov to block his path. It may be a small gesture, but it’s hi charged. Barney stares down at her. (CONTINUED )
Alma. We both know what kind of film this is. (then, closer) The smart thing to do would be to help Hitch finish it.
Thank you for your concern, Barney. She moves closer to him, holding his gaze, not bending on bit...
But on a Hitchcock picture, there is only one director. The anger flashes on his face as she faces him down, the entire crew behind her now, holding firm...
Balaban, incensed, leaves the stage with Kirkpatrick. Alm steps out into the sunlight not far behind them. As she watches them leave, she lets out a breath. A voice calls out to her --
Mrs. Hitchcock? She turns to see Janet walking over in Capri pants and a sleeveless top. She’s carrying an elegantly wrapped packa
I hope you don’t mind. I heard Hitch was sick so I got him a little something. She hands Alma the gift. A bag of candy corn tied with a ribbon.
That’s kind of you.
Well, he’s been very considerate with me. (a beat) I haven’t always had that from my directors.
Janet, you've been very... professional. It hasn't gone unappreciated. (CONTINUED )

Alma takes in Janet's unaffected natural beauty -- and he sincerity. She can’t help but notice the second glances Janet is provoking from passers-by now... She’s an impossible rival for any woman. BEETHOVEN’S 3RD SYMPHONY, ‘EROICA’ Blares deafeningly...
On the stereo. Alma finds Hitch on the sofa swaddled in a blanket and eating ICE CREAM.
May I turn that down? She silences the stereo. Hitch doesn’t react.
You'll be pleased to know order has been restored. He still doesn’t look at her, masticating loudly.
A thank you would be nice.
We're still two days behind and sixty thousand over budget.
I already cancelled the wrap party. That'll save us two thousand right there. And you won’t be tempted by any champagne and cake. She pulls at the bowl of ice cream. He refuses to let go.
Beware -- all men are potential murderers. She yanks it from his grip. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) With good reason. (CONTINUED )
Alright, what’s this about? He slowly pulls the ASPIRIN BOTTLE from his robe pocket, building suspense as he unscrews the lid and pours SAND i a tiny pile on the coffee table in front of him.
Spending a lot of time at the beach? He puts down the bottle, looking for a reaction.
That’s where Whit and I are writing. He’s rented a place.
Hardly the ideal setting to avoid distractions.
Actually, it’s very conducive to creative collaboration.
I already told you -- that treatment is a waste of time.
Didn't everyone say the same thing about “Psycho”? She reaches for the ASPIRIN BOTTLE to throw it away but H grabs it first --
Are you and Whit having an affair?
Don't be absurd. He’s working on something new and needs a little help, that’s all.
What a coincidence. I’m working on something new and I could use a little help too.
What do you think I’ve been doing? (CONTINUED )
Then why are you spending all hours of the day and night with some overage, talentless mamma’s boy?
Because it’s fun. He quivers, livid.
I am under extraordinary pressures on this picture, the least you can do is give me your full support.
Full support? We’ve mortgaged our house. My house. Alma’s eyes flash with unaccustomed hurt and fury.

Might I remind you that I have weighed-in on every aspect of this film so far, as I have done on every picture you've done in the last three decades. And the first time you show the film, it will be my notes that you want. I celebrate with you if the reviews are good and I cry for you if they are not. I host your parties and put up with those fantasy romances with your leading ladies. And when you’re out promoting this film around the world, I will stand beside or, rather, slightly behind you, smiling endlessly for the press even when I’m ready to drop, being gracious to people who look through me as if I were invisible because all they can see is the grand and glorious “Alfred Hitchcock.” Hitchcock is stunned and silent.

Now, for the first time in years, I dare to work on something that isn’t “an Alfred Hitchcock Production” and I’m met with accusation and criticisms. This work I’m doing with Whit gives me pleasure and purpose. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

And even though that takes absolutely nothing away from you, please consider this a reminder: I am your wife, Alma Reville, not one of the contract blondes you badger and torment with your oh-so- specific direction. She turns and, with great dignity, leaves Hitchcock sitti in the gathering gloom. He’s not the only one who can del a killer blow.

with that same lost expression on his face, only now dark shadow and harsh light alternate across his features. A NAKED LIGHT BULB dangles from the ceiling as STAGE HAND prepare the film’s climactic scene in the cellar. Hitch watches as VERA reaches out to touch the shoulder o Mrs. Bates. We zoom in on her as she reacts in silent hor her HAND flying up to hit the light bulb, throwing crazy shadows all over the set. We push in on Hitchcock's face as the strobing light brie illuminates the image of -
at the foot of his mother’s bed.
A WIG on a stand. A frumpy woman’s outfit on a hangar. Ve sits in front of the mirror and unties her own hair.
Free at last. Rita collects Vera's detested wardrobe to take back to wardrobe.
Thanks Rita. Vera rubs cold cream into her face to remove her make-up. the mirror, she sees Hitch in the doorway as Rita squeeze past him on her way out. (CONTINUED )
(wiping off her make-up with a Kleenex) Hello Hitch.
Well, Vera. You always make it look so easy.
Oh, it was nothing, Hitch. I just faked it. She gives him a dazzlingly ambiguous Miss America smile.
Well, I guess this is au revoir.. Hitch comes and stands behind her chair, gazing at her in mirror.

Why didn’t you stay with me? I would have made you as big a star as Grace Kelly. She considers the question and the man asking it, sensing something different about him now. She continues wiping o her make-up.

Unlike Grace Kelly, I can pick up my dry cleaning. I’ve got a family, Hitch. A home. That will always mean more to me than all of this. (then) That blonde woman of mystery you're after? She’s a fantasy. She doesn’t exist. He studies her a moment.

There was a time when I thought I understood you so completely -- understood women.... Hitch gives a very slight bow, touches her on the shoulde then leaves. Vera watches him go, struck by his rare show vulnerability.

Wind blows sand off the dunes. Alma sits in the parked ca outside the beach house, contemplating the typed pages on seat next to her. An inkling that they may not be as magi as she had hoped. No matter. She checks her reflection in the rearview and applies some lipstick, readying herself. She collects the pages and heads up the steps to the deck She sees two typewriters and paper, but no sign of Whit. Something doesn’t feel right. She turns and in the bedroom, through the window, she see Whitfield Cook making love to a young woman -- it is the pretty SECRETARY from the studio lot. Alma and Whit's eye meet. Whit is horrified at being caught. Alma ducks her head, wheels around in shock. ALMA’S CAR She yanks open the door and gets in. Whit runs half dress from the house...
Alma, I thought you were coming later tonight.
I thought you rented this place so we could write.
I did. I swear -- this just happened. She struggles to get the key in the ignition. He puts his hand desperately on the car door. WHITFIELD COOK (CONT’D) You won't say anything, will you?
Don't worry. I won't tell Elizabeth.
I mean to Hitch. Whit smiles feebly. WHITFIELD COOK (CONT’D) We can’t all be geniuses. (CONTINUED )
Alma tries to hide what a body blow this is. WHITFIELD COOK (CONT’D) Alma -- you're incredibly talented. But, after all... we want him to read the script with an open mind.
Oh, I wouldn't worry about that, Whit. She starts the car and drives off. Whit watches, deflated, knowing he’s ruined everything, h receding figure swallowed up by flickering white light...

head_text.subj: WE PLAY THIS SCENE ONLY OVER THE FACES OF A SMALL INVITED
ARE SEEING IS NOT GOING OVER WELL. NOT AT ALL.

text: Lew sits with Barney Balaban and two executives. Lew discreetly checks his watch out of boredom. Shurlock and two Assistants look appalled. Composer BERNARD HERRMANN, 40s, prickly, sits in the back row looking suicidal. He glances back at Hitchcock who stands near the screening r door looking worse, if that could be possible.
Shurlock exits and approaches Hitchcock who’s waiting in foyer.
You're going to have to cut all that nudity.
What nudity? It was suggested.
I definitely saw that knife jabbing her.
We did no such shot.
I'd stake my reputation on it. I'm recommending you cut the shower scene entirely. Hitchcock is livid but holds his tongue. (CONTINUED )

I'll go over it frame by frame and set up another screening. But Shurlock is already walking away... Wasserman emerges from the screening room conversing with BALABAN. Hitch searches their expressions for some indica but Balaban strides off without saying a single word to h ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) What’s the verdict?
Let’s just say it was a four-letter review and it wasn’t ‘good’. The harsh reality devastates Hitchcock.
Screw him. It's too late for Paramount to back out no matter what Balaban says. Hitch just stands there.
The other route is to recut it as a two- parter for the TV series. Because of the budget and the Hitchcock name, we stand a good chance of breaking even. Still, Hitch doesn’t say a word.

Look, I made Jimmy Stewart a millionaire of Winchester 73 and that was a dog. At least I could sit through your picture. Hitch stares bleakly off. He can’t help noticing the KIM NOVAK-TYPE he spied on earlier outside, hand in hand and kissing her date.
More importantly, what does Alma think?
Alma sits with the Hitchcocks’ ACCOUNTANT going over the books again, looking at the revised figures. They close t books and sit back and look at each other.
Is there anything else we can do? (CONTINUED )
Silence. This time he can’t bring himself to look her in eye.

We'll just have to wait and see how the movie turns out. Alma gets up and crosses to the window. Stares out at the pool reflecting a leaden sky... and the clumps of dead le floating across its surface...
Well, it is only a house.
The dogs, GEOFFREY and STANLEY, lap away at a water bowl the study. A splash or two of something is added to the b from above. It’s being poured from Hitch’s brandy glass.

pours himself another glass, leaving the dogs lapping hap away as he goes over to the Steinway Grand. There’s a ban silver-framed PHOTOS on top. He pauses to take a proper l at them. His and Alma’s life together in movies. Smiling at Premie with Cary Grant and Grace Kelly. On vacation with Jimmy a Gloria Stewart. At a black tie event with Ingrid Bergman Gregory Peck. But it’s the PHOTOGRAPH tucked away at the back that he w to see most. A BLACK AND WHITE PUBLICITY STILL taken on the set of The Mountain Eagle in 1926. He picks it up and looks at it: The young Hitchcock in front of the camera, dramatically calling “Action!” on his first film. His eyes don’t have move far to find ALMA, standing just behind him, making n on her clipboard, the same intense, serious look on her f They look so young... Hitch turns to look out the window, thoughtful -- Hitch’s POV. It’s SNOWING outside.
We pull back to discover the window is now in a basement by a single oil lamp. (CONTINUED )
We find Gein sitting at his workbench. Hitchcock is perch on a stool nearby watching him. Trash and newspapers are piled everywhere. There is grime dark stains on the cabinets and counters.

This is my favorite place. I just shut the doors and leave the world behind. Hitch watches Gein as he threads a needle, stitching something expertly together. He notices there’s no hint o tremble in Gein’s hands. ED GEIN (CONT’D) Pass me that bag, will you? Hitch passes over the shopping bag... then pulls up his c feeling a chill.
Don’t you get lonely out here sometimes?
I can always talk to my mother.

As we hear CARS pull up -- a lot of them. The sound of ME shouting. Flashing RED AND BLUE LIGHTS. LOUD KNOCKING at door -- ED GEIN (CONT’D) That’s strange. FOOTSTEPS thunder above him. DOZENS OF OFFICERS are fanni out all over the house.
Jesus Christ. Hitch watches as Gein just sits there and the sound of SHOCKED reactions and horrified GASPS continue above... CAPTAIN SCHOEPHOERSTER (CONT’D) I think we found his hiding spot.
(sotto voce) They can’t go in there. That’s my mother’s room... (CONTINUED )

CAR HEADLIGHTS blast through the window and Hitchcock fin sees the basement room properly for the first time; KNIVE all shapes and sizes...JARS OF PRESERVED BODY PARTS...and SEVERED HANDS, FOLDED IN PRAYER. FROM UPSTAIRS the sound of splintering wood. ED GEIN (CONT’D) They can’t go in there! (calling out) That’s my mother’s room!! Ed springs to his feet, screaming it out as he BOLTS UPST and the pandemonium continues (o.s.) WE PUSH IN ON HITCH’S FACE As the bleak reality of Gein’s lair hits him... It’s more profound and horrible than he could ever have imagined. A lush ROMANTIC SCORE starts to SWELL, mercifully drownin all out...
Titles from a dark 1946 romantic melodrama fill the scree “THE SECRET HEART” “SCREENPLAY BY WHITFIELD COOK.” Alma sits watching the afternoon movie alone, brushing th dogs on the sofa next to her.
Hitchcock reads Alma’s fragile emotional state and enters sits down beside her and studies the screen for a moment.
An odd little movie. Of course, Colbert is wonderful. Alma nods. They watch for a beat longer. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) How was the beach?
Cold and miserable. (CONTINUED )

Just like Barney Balaban’s face. He indicates the over-ripe dialogue coming from the TV. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Whit isn’t worth a damn when he’s not working with you. (pause) And neither am I. Alma takes in his reflective expression, but says nothing ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) I didn't pull off the picture this time. It just sits there, refusing to come to life. (then) There’s no other way to say it... It’s stillborn. ALMA turns away. Hitch sits there bereft in the lonely silence. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) I let you down, my love. He moves closer and takes her hand. Gives it a small sque ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) You deserved better. She still doesn’t move. After a moment Hitch gets to his feet. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) I’ll go and feed Geoffrey and Stanley, shall I. He exits with the dogs padding after him. She turns back the screen and more of that stilted, mannered dialogue. Tears well in her eyes.
A full moon. The ONLY LIGHT from inside the house is the in the kitchen. We glimpse the figure in the window. A corpulent man in profile, like a Hopper painting.

Hitch sits in his nightgown, pushing some VEGETABLES arou his plate -- his healthy midnight snack. Alma enters in her robe. Hitch watches her. She goes to t fridge, opens the PRODUCE DRAWER and from under the bruss sprouts pulls out a tiny hidden jar of BELUGA CAVIAR. She gets the crackers, a plate and a spoon and sits down the table next to him.
I don't think I can stand both of us being maudlin. She fixes several crackers, each with an appropriate doll of caviar on top, and puts the plate in the middle.
There is one solution to all this, you know. She offers him one of the crackers.
We could both get to work -- together. Tentatively, Hitch accepts it.
That tiresome little Hitchcock imitation I've been helping Whit finish is done. Hitch remains quiet, delicately consuming his cracker.

So I suggest, for everyone’s sake, we start whipping Psycho into shape tomorrow. You may not be the easiest man to live with but you know how to cut a picture better than anyone. Hitch puts the lid back on the caviar.
Except for you.
A series of quick shots as the editing room comes to life

head_text.subj: CANS OF FILM ARE BROUGHT IN BY ASSISTANTS, STRIPS OF
CELLULOID ARE PULLED OUT, INSPECTED AND MARKED WITH CHALK

text: HITCH and editor GEORGE TOMASINI wait quietly like schoolboys, while Alma reviews the footage on the Moviola
You’1l need to cut those six or seven frames where she blinks after she’s supposed to be dead.
We've seen the footage a thousand times. She doesn't blink. Alma gives him a look ...
FOUR ASSISTANTS are working on MOVIOLAS. Alma and Hitch w their way down the line, inspecting each new assembly.
(first moviola) Take thirty frames off the head...
No, no, the second take, the light is better on his hands.
(next moviola) Only cut back to Janet once the car’s already moving.

Cut it tighter. The minute I lose one person I've lost the whole audience. TWO PAIRS OF HANDS. Hitchcock's and Alma's. They work lik pair of twenty-year-olds at a pair of MOVIOLAS cutting th picture. ANGLE LOOSENS -- to reveal George Tomasini has dozed off, exhausted. (CONTINUED )
You imp. You got nudity in there.
Her breasts are very large, dear. It was a challenge not to show them.
Editor GEORGE TOMASINI works at the Moviola, sleeves roll up.
I'll be damned. She did blink.
Peggy stands with a pestering PR FLACK.
How’s it going in there with Mr. Herrmann?
Swimmingly.
Everyone’s saying it’s a dog with fleas. Before Peggy can deny it the argument flares through the wall.
Absolutely not...
Bernard Herrmann is pressing his point hard with Hitchcoc
...-I don’t want music in the shower murder.
(frustrated) But what Alma and I talked about is really going to play.
No. This isn’t Vertigo, Bernie. This is different. The images have to work on their own. (CONTINUED )
You can't scare people just by going, “Boo!” You have to tell them what’s coming, make them anticipate it --
The PR Flack shares a despairing look with Peggy.
Thank God we've got Cinderfella for the holidays.
BERNARD HERRMANN’S ICONIC SCORE RISES as

We move across HITCH, ALMA, TOMASINI and PEGGY’S faces as they watch the Moviola. The impact of the music is instant and unimaginably power They are all moved. Gripped. Stunned. Hitchcock looks down. Peggy is gripping his arm tightly.
What do you think?
I think I'm never going to take a shower again.
Hitch? They look at him...
It's getting there. Alma turns to him and Hitch nods slightly. Was that the tiniest acknowledgement that her instinct may have been right?
ON SHURLOCK’'S HUMORLESS FACE Hitchcock sits opposite him at the big conference table. (CONTINUED )
I told you, I distinctly saw both the stabbing and the nudity. We're denying your seal, Mr. Hitchcock.

I take your opinion very seriously. But what you think you're seeing is purely informed by the power of suggestion. I assure you that once you view the final version with Mr. Herrmann's lovely, lyrical score...
A “lyrical score” won't change my opinion. All that innuendo and half-naked groping -- really, Hitch.

Would you mind if we had a word in private, Geoffrey? Shurlock gestures his staff out. Hitch moves closer. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) I have a modest proposal to make. If you're willing to leave the shower sequence as it is, I will reshoot the opening love scene to your exact specifications. Shurlock reacts with surprise. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) In fact, I'd welcome your personal supervision on the set. Shurlock is more flattered than he’d care to admit.
My specifications?
If only audiences could fully appreciate how tirelessly you work to help us entertain them while protecting them from filth and indecency. Shurlock studies Hitchcock’s sphinx-like expression.
Hitchcock and Peggy confer. John Gavin and Janet Leigh, wearing robes, chat while lying on a bed. Crew members wa impatiently. Peggy checks her watch.
He's been harassing you since you announced this project, you invite him to the set, and he doesn’t even show up? What did you tell him?

That I respected him. Deeply. Peggy laughs. Now she understands. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Ladies and gentleman, that is a wrap. Thank you all. The crew starts breaking things down. The actors are baff Janet walks over to him.
I thought we were reshooting the scene.
No need. The charade is over. Hitch holds out his arm for her and walks her back to the dressing room. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) See, I wasn’t that much of a monster to work with, was I?
Not at all. He offers his hand and she shakes it, determined to be professional to the end.
I just hope I was sufficiently loyal to the cause.
Worthy of a Purple Heart, my dear. She leans in and gives him a peck on the cheek. A moment unexpected heaven that leaves Hitch speechless. (CONTINUED )

She walks away to her dressing room. Hitch watches as she steps inside and closes the door. After a moment we hear a PIERCING SCREAM -- INT. JANET LEIGH’S DRESSING ROOM - CONTINUOUS Janet recoils at the sight of A MRS. BATES PROTOTYPE “PRO MASK" grinning lewdly from her chair, and wearing one of Janet's brassieres. Hitchcock peeks inside as crew members come running.
I hope you don’t mind, I told Mrs. Bates she could have your dressing room.
She can’t believe she’s been caught out. She closes the d on everyone... and then after a moment SCREAMS AGAIN... b this time not out of shock.
Hitch sweeps in. Lew is waiting for him.
We have our seal from Shurlock’s office. (devilishly) Now, we lead the lambs to the slaughter. Hitch turns to Lew for the latest news.
The front office confirmed. They’re only opening the movie in two theatres, as we suspected. And no premiere. If we don’t get word of mouth we’re dead.
Then we'd better get started. Peggy, take a memo... Peggy whips out her steno pad. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) We're going to write a manual on exactly how to sell Psycho.
BOOKLETS make the rounds on a conveyor-like contraption. the booklets are bound by swift-moving WORKERS, we see Hitchcock's photo on a cover and his “advice” to theater owners.
My first instruction to Theater Owners: Hire Pinkerton guards to strictly enforce our unique admission policies.
A MANAGER opens up his PSYCHO PROMOTIONAL HANDBOOK and st to read, totally baffled.
Furthermore, because Psycho is so terrifying and unique, the guards can help you deal with customers who run amok.
The manager introduces the PINKERTON GUARDS to his equall bemused STAFF.
Post our special lobby clocks to remind audiences of the starting times for Psycho. He oversees as they hang a ridiculously large PSYCHO CLOC the lobby.
Hitch’s voice booms from LARGE SPEAKERS MOUNTED UNDER THE MARQUEE.

The manager of this fine motion picture theater has been advised not to allow anyone to enter the theater once Psycho begins. We PAN DOWN to the STAFF and GUARDS as they test out the RECORDED message that will be played for the ticket holde line. A couple of PASSERSBY listen, perplexed... (CONTINUED )
ALFRED HITCHCOCK (V.0O.) (CONT’D) Should you be so foolish as to attempt to slip in by a side entrance...
.»+. a fire escape or through a skylight, you will be ejected by brute force. Hitch lays down the track into a large microphone while A watches from the recording desk.
More playful, darling.
A row of life-size HITCHCOCK STANDEES are carried in thro the door one by one. Posters are hung in the theatre lobb The letters hoisted up and hung on the marquee outside.

“To further emphasize the sheer, unrelenting shock and suspense of Psycho, right after the closing title “THE END,” we strongly recommend that you close your house curtains over the screen for a full thirty seconds.” Inside the theatre, the manager makes sure the CURTAINS o and close correctly then turns to face the vast, empty auditorium.
“By doing so, the horror of Psycho will be indelibly etched in the mind and heart of your audience.” He anxiously surveys the hundreds of seats that will have be filled.
Now Barney Balaban is reading Hitchcock's publicity manua the board. (CONTINUED )

“Absolutely never, ever will I allow anything to follow Psycho -- no previews of coming attractions, no newsreel, no short subject and certainly no double- feature. Sincerely, and, emphatically, Alfred Hitchcock.” Balaban shuts the pamphlet. Silence. Then turns to the st faced board members : BARNEY BALABAN (CONT’D) At the end of the day, it’s a minor Hitchcock movie. One week, and it'll be gone... He tosses the pamphlet into the trash.
Like a bad dream.
ON HITCH AND ALMA’S SILENT TENSE EXPRESSIONS as they driv through the frenetic madness that typifies Times Square, 1960.
A DAZZLING MARQUEE for “ALFRED HITCHCOCK'S PSYCHO.” The c pulls up. Hitch and Alma step out. There’s a long line of people outside the theatre.
Well, at least there are some people here. But Hitch’s nerves are hardly soothed. The people in line start to notice the Hitchcocks...is it really them?
Comes over to greet them with the THEATRE MANAGER.
We can go through the side entrance. As the theatre manager ushers them through the side alley (CONTINUED )
Right this way, Mr. and Mrs. Hitchcock. Hitchcock turns to Alma.
Ready for the gallows?
The atmosphere is tense as people hurry to their seats. L greets them.
We've roped off some seats for you.
You go on ahead.
Are you sure?
I‘1l join you in a minute. Off Alma’s look. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) I want to double check the print.
Fine, darling. I'll save you a seat. Lew escorts Alma and Peggy into the auditorium.
The soothing whir of the projector as Hitchcock stands ne to it... but the sound of the audience below TITTERING NERVOUSLY is anything but reassuring.
(under his breath) But they’re laughing too much. He peers down through the tiny window but can’t see a blo thing.
Hitch inches open the door and PEERS THROUGH THE CRACK at audience but now he can’t read them. Are they gripped wit suspense -- or do they just hate it? From the lobby we see

as he closes the door and leans back against the wall of empty corridor. A scared, lonely, corpulent figure. Total powerless. There’s nothing for him to do but wait. And wait. And wait. Across the foyer, a spotty young THEATRE EMPLOYEE sweeps ticket stubs and empties ashtrays, quietly going about hi business, entirely oblivious... ON HITCH’S FACE As he grips the railing. This is taking far too long. And then -- finally -- the sweetest sound in the world A BLOOD-CURDLING SCREAM. Soon the WHOLE AUDIENCE SCREAMS IN TERROR... then breaks LAUGHTER again... nervous laughter this time, the best ki
As he gestures with his hands, a conductor leading his orchestra, raising them up again as the audience STARTS SCREAMING AGAIN right on cue
As the dam breaks and all the pent-up emotion floods out. leaving only relief and satisfaction... and making way fo smile... the largest of his whole career.
Hitch, Alma and Peggy are led out into the foyer by the theatre manager. There are still SCREAMS in the theatre a the show continues. (CONTINUED )

Lew can be seen on the phone in the theatre manager’s off in the background as Hitch, Alma and Peggy walk past the of ticket buyers to get to the front doors. There is grea excitement now as more and more people recognize the Hitchcocks...
Mr. Hitchcock, how does it end?
I promised Mother I wouldn't tell. He gets a laugh. Hitchcock walks alongside the Theater Manager who’s not going to miss out on having his own mom with the crowd.
Mr. Hitchcock, what do I do now that my wife won't take a shower after seeing your movie?
Have her dry-cleaned. Laughter as Lew appears.
I just got off the phone with Balaban. I couldn't resist telling him we’re sold out for the next two weeks.
What did he say?
He said “Tell Hitch congratulations. A well deserved triumph as we always knew.”
“As we always knew...” The two friends a look.
Does this mean I can take the weekend off now? Hitch playfully shrugs, “we’ll see”.
I’m sorry, Mr. Hithcock but there are photographers outside. They heard you were here. (CONTINUED )
The theatre manager ushers them towards the exit doors.

A few photographers snap Hitch as he emerges and heads pa the line of ticket buyers towards the waiting car. Hitchc gestures for Alma to take her place next to him instead o behind him. She shyly waves him away but eventually, and appreciatively, relents. As the flashbulbs start to POP --
This could be the biggest hit of your career, Alfred.

Our career, Alma. He looks into her eyes with nothing but deep, intense gratitude and joy. As more flashbulbs pop -- ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) I’ve realized I’1l never be able to find a Hitchcock blonde as beautiful as you.
You do realize I've been waiting decades to hear you say that. He gives her a gentle peck.
And that, madame, is why they call me “The Master of Suspense”... He helps her into the car.

It is a utilitarian institutionalized dining room. Severa nonviolent INMATES eat at different round tables around t room. An ATTENDANT watches, and an ORDERLY mops the floor (ther are NO female patients nor staff members.)
(CONTINUED )
is at a table with two other patients, including a soft spoken older man, CHET. Ed is heavier, his hair is whiter and he is much more at ease than we've ever seen.
(to the Attendant) Guess what I'm doing this weekend?
What?

Claudine and I are driving to Chicago with her folks to see that Psycho movie. The Attendant pulls the orderly aside, and whispers to hi nodding toward Ed. The Orderly's jaw drops! It is the coo thing he's ever heard. He looks at Ed like he's a movie s Meanwhile, Ed yawns, content. Utterly oblivious.
I think you're the happiest guy I've ever known, Ed. How you do it?

I‘1l tell you. You live your life, and it's unbearable sometimes but there's this secret, Chet; a big secret no one else knows or wants to tell... (he leans a little closer) «+. there is a God and he’s so big and powerful, he doesn’t always remember you're there... He takes a huge bite blueberry pie. ED GEIN (CONT’D) .»+. but if you can get his attention and he sees you're suffering, he’ll notice and he'll take care of you. My mother used to tell me -- she’s passed, God bless her -- the one thing God truly loves and understands is suffering. He takes a long drink of milk.
After all, he invented it. We pan to discover HITCHCOCK has been watching all this. turns to the camera. (CONTINUED )

And so, gentle viewer, Psycho -- the picture everyone predicted would bring me to wrack and ruin -- was such a hit that Alma and I got to... Well, let’s just say that we got to keep our house -- and the swimming pool. And the same critics who despised it went on to call it one of my greatest achievements. He produces a CIGAR and wanders towards the exit doors. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Of course for me, it was just another “moo-vie.” As he strolls through the door --
-- and seamlessly appears in the beautifully tended garde as if having walked through a portal.

But you know what they say in Hollywood: “You're only as good as your last picture.” So, now, if you'll excuse me, I must toddle off to begin the exhaustive search for my next project. He holds out his cigar towards something we don’t yet see ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Unfortunately I find myself once again bereft of all inspiration. I do hope something comes along soon...
Alights on his cigar tip and FLAPS its wings. Hitchcock c resist blowing a sadistic plume of smoke at the bird whic promptly flies away. He gives the camera a final characteristically deadpan look...
Good evening. The distinctive THEME TUNE to his TV show starts up and H toddles back up the front lawn and toward the terrace, wh Alma can be seen laying out a delicious healthy lunch...
(CONTINUED )

head_text.subj: ALFRED HITCHCOCK MADE SIX MORE MOVIES AFTER PSYCHO. HE DI
AT HOME IN BEL AIR IN 1980, WITH ALMA BY HIS SIDE. ALMA
ED GEIN LIVED IN COMFORT IN MENTAL INSTITUTIONS UNTIL HIS
ALFRED HITCHCOCK NEVER WON AN OSCAR. IN 1979, WHEN HE
ACCEPTED THE AMERICAN FILM INSTITUTE'S LIFE ACHIEVEMENT

text: AWARD, HE DEDICATED THE HONOR TO HIS WIFE, SAYING, “I SHA MY AWARD, AS I HAVE MY LIFE, WITH ALMA.” FADE OUT.
